resources.string: No Maps app found on your device.

Dedicated to Bhagwan Swaminarayan, Akshardham Temple exhibits the ancient culture of India.

The temple complex maintains a step-well styled courtyard and 60 acres of lush lawns featuring the bronze statues of Indian heroes, including patriots and warriors. Registered as the World's largest comprehensive Hindu temple in the Guinness World Record, the temple is an architectural marvel built from intricately carved sandstone and marble.

Furthermore, the temple organizes exhibitions on Swaminarayan's life teachings and also organises a musical fountain and light show after sunset every day.
Akshardham, Metro Station Akshardham, Noida Link Road, Ganesh Nagar, New Delhi, Delhi

Constructed in 1639 by the Mughals, Red Fort gets its name from its massive red-coloured sandstone walls.

Set in Old Delhi, the octagonal-shaped fort is spread over an area of 254 acres. The planning and designing of the fort is a fusion of Mughal, Persian, Hindu, and Timurid traditions.

A strong influence on later structures built in and around Delhi, Red Fort also features a museum that holds Mughal-era artefacts, including daggers, curtains, miniature paintings and carpets. The highlights of this architectural creativity include the peacock throne, step well, imperial bath, Moti Masjid and Hira Mahal.
Saraf Hospital J6WR+JXV, Daryaganj, New Delhi, Delhi 110002

India Gate symbolises the sacrifice of 70,000 Indian soldiers who lost their lives battling against the foreign army during the World War I.

Designed by Edwin Lutyens, it features the undying Amar Jawan Jyoti or the Flame of the Immortal Soldier which was added later to honour Indian martyred soldiers in the Indo-Pak War. Furthermore, this beautiful masterpiece is counted amongst the largest war memorials in India.

Standing on a Bharatpur stone base, the structure is surrounded by lush lawns making it a popular picnic spot during winter afternoons and summer evenings. Lit at night, the monument looks magnificent with colourful fountains in the in the vicinity.
Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital, Delhi 110001

A world-class amusement park, Worlds of Wonder ensures a fun-filled quality-time with your friends and family amidst a variety of attractions.

Popularly known as WOW, it maintains over 20 rides, including Mega Disco, Download, Chart Smashers, Feedback, Fast Forward, Big Beat and Rockin Roller. Its La Fiesta zone, which is meant for your little ones exclusively, features rides like Hippti Hopp, Loco Motion, Space Shot and Samba Rhumba.

Spread over 10 acres of land, the theme park is additionally popular for water rides and go-karting, and also features a pool bar, snack bar and Punjabi dhaba.
For Amusement Park and Water Park: Adults - ₹ 1000 | Children - ₹ 800
Botanical Garden Metro Station Uttar Pradesh 201301
Bhardwaj Hospital, Nh-1, Sector - 29 Opposite Ganga Shopping Complex, Noida, Uttar Pradesh 201301
Sector 29 Police Station, 40, Dadri Main Rd, Bhangel, Salarpur Khadar, Sector - 106, Noida, Uttar Pradesh 201303

Set in the heart of National Capital and popularly known as CP, Connaught Place is considered as the most expensive commercial markets in the world.

It is popular for housing showrooms of national and international brands, luxurious hotels and flea markets. The equinoctial sundial, Jantar Mantar, and Gurudwara Bangla Sahib featuring a reflecting pool, are extremely popular among tourists visiting Connaught Place.

Notably, the commercial area got its name from Prince Arthur, 1st Duke of Connaught and Strathearn.
Police Chauki, J6P7+5V7, Lady Hardinge Medical College, Munrika, New Delhi, Delhi 110001

An outdoor marketplace located near INA Market, Dilli Haat is spread over 6 acres with 62 stalls presenting handicrafts and ethnic cuisine from various parts of India.

It offers a traditional rural ambience where visitors can admire the rich Indian culture and shop for items suitable to their modern-day requirements.

Moreover, Dilli Haat organizes many cultural events, including dance and music performances, and aims to preserve the heritage of India.
Police Sahayata Kendra- Police Station, Delhi 110023

Qutub Minar is a 73-metre tall minaret, named after Qutb-ud-din Aibak.

The tower contains 5 distinct tapering storeys, wherein first 3 storeys of this masterpiece are adorned with red sandstone, while the fourth and fifth storeys are constructed in marble and sandstone respectively, engraved with decorative Quranic texts.

Interestingly, the tower has a spiral staircase with 379 steps, and has a mosque named ‘Quwwat-ul-Islam Masjid’ at the foot of the tower, which is the first mosque in India.
Qutab Minar Metro Station, Mittal Garden, Sainik Farm, New Delhi, Delhi 110030

Built in 1565 A.D., the Humayun’s Tomb was established in the memory of Humayun by his widow Bega Begam, and was the first example of Mughal architecture in India.

Constructed after nine years of his demise, the tomb is inspired by Persian architecture which is reflected in the corridors arched alcoves, and the double dome.

The tomb is also called chaharbagh, owing to its garden squares with passageways water channels, and holds graves of Mughal rulers inside the walled enclosed space.
Hazrat Nizamuddin Metro Station, Block A, Ganga Vihar, Sarai Kale Khan, New Delhi, Delhi 110013

Known for its unique architectural design, Lotus Temple is a Bahá’í House of Worship, dedicated to harmony of humanity.

Inspired by the lotus flower, the temple boasts of 27 free-standing marble-clad petals, and is surrounded by sprawling gardens and pond. With a height of over 34 metres, it can accommodate around 2500 people altogether.

The temple welcomes every religion symbolizing the culture of Bahá’í Houses of Worship, and offers a tranquil ambience ideal for rejuvenation.
Apollo Spectra Hospitals, 13, Kailash Rd, Sant Nagar, East of Kailash, New Delhi, Delhi 110065
Police Post Nehru Place, Nehru Place South Delhi, near Place Market, New Delhi, Delhi 110019

If there is one place in NCR that all fun seekers swear by, it’s Cyber Hub Gurgaon.

It is an integrated food and entertainment destination with multiple offices, mainly occupying the higher floors of the buildings within the complex. Along the promenade that makes its way through these buildings are an array of dining options including restaurants, bars & pubs, cafes, bakeries, dessert places, and so on.

Places like Smaaash and The People and Co. lift the entertainment quotient even further. There are a few retail outlets as well, along with an amphitheatre for events and promotional activities.
Most of the dining venues remain open till midnight.
IndusInd Bank Cyber City Metro Station, Haryana 122022

First of its kind in India, Delhi’s National Rail Museum houses the largest collection of life-size railway exhibits including locomotives, coaches and simulators collected from different princely states of the country.

The indoor galleries within this 11-acre museum also preserve documents, drawings, books, maps and other items that take you on a journey through over 160 years of Indian Railway.

Toy Train 1:8, 3D Virtual Coach Ride, Joy Train and PSMT Ride are the major attractions at this museum.
Monday to Thursday: 10:00 am to 5:00 pm\nFriday, Saturday & Sunday: 6:00 pm to 9:00 pm
Weekdays: Adults - ₹ 50 | Children - ₹ 10\nWeekends and Holidays: Adults - ₹ 100 | Children - ₹ 20\nFor Night Entry (Friday-Sunday): Adults - ₹ 200 | Children - ₹ 150
Sir Vishweshariah Moti Bagh Metro Station, Delhi 110021

When in New Delhi, don’t miss out on exploring the Rashtrapati Bhavan, the official residence of the President of India.

Flanked on the western end of Rajpath, this sprawling 330-acre estate houses the Main Building (Circuit 1), the Rashtrapati Bhavan Museum Complex (Circuit 2) and the world-famous Mughal Gardens (Circuit 3).

A creation of Sir Edwin Lutyens and Herbert Baker, this huge presidential palace is the largest home of any head of state in the world and is truly an architectural marvel.

9:00 am to 4:00 pm
Circuit 1: Open on Thursday-Sunday.
Circuit 2: Open on all days except Monday.
Circuit 3: Open on Thursday-Sunday (November-March).
Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital, Delhi 110001

Jantar Mantar is one of the most popular places to visit in Delhi.

This UNESCO World Heritage Site houses the equinoctial sundial that can measure the time of the day based on the sun’s movements.

There are a total of 13 astronomy architectural instruments here and you can spend a couple of hours enjoying their precision and build.
Police Chauki, J6P7+5V7, Lady Hardinge Medical College, Munrika, New Delhi, Delhi 110001

Chandni Chowk is translated as Moonlight Street. This iconic area in Delhi houses one of the oldest markets in the city.

You can buy everything you want at wholesale prices here. The hustle and bustle of the street, the colourful and quaint stores, and the constant banter between buyers and sellers are experiences you should not miss.

Chandni Chowk has about 1500+ shops.
Most shops remain open between 10:00 AM and 7:00 PM on all days except Mondays.

Lodhi Gardens is a park in the city that is spread over 90 acres and is surrounded by a beautifully maintained landscape.\n\nIt contains the tombs of Sikander Lodi, Mohammed Shah, Bara Gumbad, and Shisha Gumbad. The 15th-century architectural work is exquisite here. You can spend a couple of hours in the morning here exploring the grounds.
Khan Market Metro Station, Sujan Sing Park North, Sujan Singh Park, New Delhi, Delhi 110003
Police Station, 53, Prithviraj Ln, Prithiviraj Market, Khan Market, Rabindra Nagar, New Delhi, Delhi 110003

Connaught Place is the place in Delhi for food - no matter what your budget is. From fancy fine-dining restaurants to the delicious local rajma chawal. Connaught Place has food for everyone\'s budget.\n\nWith the best restaurants in the city, Connaught Place is an area that has all kinds of cuisine - local and international. Some joints you definitely should try out are Kake Da Hotel, Parikrama, Jain Chawal Wale, and Minar.
Tom Kha Soup, Pan Fried Noodles, Chicken Drumstick, Dal Makhani, and Honey Chilli Potato.
G 2/43, Middle Circle, Connaught Place, New Delhi
Paneer Labbabdar, Veg Kebab Platter, Dal Ardor, and Chilli Chicken Dry
N 55 to 56 & 88 to 89, Outer Circle, Connaught Place, New Delhi

Chilli Paneer, Fragrant Chicken, Sushi, Prawn Pepper Salt, Sauteed Chinese Greens, Pasta Cheesecake, Fish French Fries, Spring Roll Noodles, Fried Rice, Manchow Soup Honey, Chilli Potato, and Manchurian.
Cheese Nachos, Dahi Ke Kebab, Crispy Chilli Potatoes, and Non Vegetarian Shahi Platter
D-19/20, 1st Floor, Inner Circle, Connaught Place, New Delhi
Dosa, Idli, Gulab Jamun, Butter Chicken, Paratha, and Fish Noodles.
P 13, Connaught Circus, Connaught Place, New Delhi
Butter Masala Dosa, Dahi Vada, Uttappam, Mysore Masala Dosa, Paneer Dosa, Onion Rava Dosa, Mini Idli, and Chettinad Dosa.
Penne Arrabiata Sauce, Speedy Nachos, and Lord Of Veggies.
G-72, 1st Floor, Outer Circle, Connaught Place, New Delhi

If there\'s one place you\'ve got to visit, particularly if you\'re vegetarian, it\'s Paranthe Wali Gali. Several tiny shops serving delicious paranthe, fresh, hot and in a variety of styles. In existence for over 50 years, some of the original shops are still operating.\n\nSeveral celebrities and influential politicians and businessmen also visit this place, which is crowded through the evening and into the night.
Traditional parathas like Paneer, Aloo-Pyaz, Gobi, and Pudina Paratha.
Gali Paranthe Wali, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi
Kachori Subzi, Khasta Kachori, and Dal Kachori.
1104, Jogiwari, Gali Paranthe Wali, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi
Nagori Matar Samosa, Gajar Halwa, Gulabjamun, and Lassi.
Shop Number 4, Tiraha Kinari Bazar, Paranthe Wali Gali, Chandni Chowk, Old Delhi
Bikaner Mixture, Dal Biji, Kashmiri Mixture, Matthris, Anarkali and Shahi Toast.
Corner Gali Paranthe Wali, Opposite Central Blank, Chandni Chowk, Old Delhi
Papad Parantha, Meva Parantha, Karela Parantha, Dal Aloo Parantha and Lemon Parantha.

Food in Delhi is incomplete without a visit to this area. If you eat meat and love street food, Jama Masjid area is the place to be!\n\nJama Masjid and the lane opposite, Bazaar Matia Mahal, have some of the best non-vegetarian street food in Delhi. From keema samosas to grilled boti to kebabs and jalebi, this area is a paradist for foodies.
Near churi walan gali, chitti qabar road, New Delhi
Jama Masjid, Matial Mahal Road Opposite Gate No.1, New Delhi
Gate no. 1, Near Jama Masjid, Urdu Bazar, New Delhi
No. 113, Matia Mahal Rd, Jama Masjid, Bazar Matia Mahal, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi
Outside Hamdard shop in Chitli Qabar
Paneer Pakora, Khoya Samosa, and Panner Ki Jalebi.
Shop No. 4–5, Matia Mahal Road, Opposite Jama Masjid Gate No. 1, Matia Mahal, New Delhi

Karol Bagh has an eclectic blend of all kinds of Indian cuisine. From street food, and shakes to dhabas and restaurants, it has some amazing food options.\n\nRoshan Di Kulfi, Anjalika, Om Corner Chhole Bhature, Art of Spices, Sindhi Corner, Sandoz, and Changezi are some of our favorites and we definitely recommend checking them out.
3-A, New Rohtak Road, East Park Road, Shidi Pura, Dori Walan, Near HDFC Bank, Karol Bagh
B ⅓ Behind City Hospital, Pusa Road, Karol Bagh
Sant Nagar DB Gupta Road, Karol Bagh

Khan Market is one of Delhi\'s incredible food districts. It has a mix of cafes, fine dining options and fast food. A vibrant neighbourhood, whose streets are filled with the delicious aromas of mutton kebab and fried rice, it is a hub for the best eateries, bars and restaurants.\n\nA few restaurants here that you absolutely must visit are The Big Chill, Yellow Brick Road Restaurant, Wok in the Clouds, Azam\'s Mughlai, and Cafe Turtle.
61 Khan Market, Rabindra Nagar, New Delhi

Another street best food in Delhi, which you most certainly shouldn\'t miss, is Nizamuddin. There are dozens of amazing eateries in this area and you will find delicious kebabs, sweets, and Mughlai delicacies.\n\nAll you meat-lovers out there should definitely try out Karim\'s, Gulgam Kashmiri Wazwan, and Ghalib Kebab Corner.
Nayab Mughz Masala and Gurda Keliji.
Shop No. 168/2, Nizammudin West Slum, Delhi 110013
Mirza Ghalib\'s Grave, Nizamuddin West, Delhi 110013
8, Nizamuddin East Market, Block B, Delhi 110003

Whether you are in the mood for street food, snacks, fast food, or multi-cuisine diners, North Campus is a place where you\'ll find all of these.\n\nSince this is a university area, the food is pocket friendly, and the numerous options available service delicious food. We recommend you try out Momo\'s Point, Bille Di Hatti, Chache Di Hatti, Shagun Asian Eatery, Bamboo Hut, and South Indian Cafe.
2524, 1st Floor, Hudson Lane, Delhi University - GTB Nagar
2526, 1st Floor, Hudson Lane, Kingsway Camp, Delhi University - GTB Nagar
522, Ground Floor, Hudson Lane, Delhi University - GTB Nagar
Banoffe Pie and Chunky Monke Shake.
2520, 1st Floor, Hudson Lane, Kingsway Camp, Delhi University - GTB Nagar
Near Rajmas College, Maurice Nagar Chowk, North Campus, Delhi University - GTB Nagar

If you are a college student or just someone on a tight budget, in search of some delicious food, South Campus is a great option, with a variety of awesome cafes.\n\nThe cafes here mostly serve shakes, fast food, American and Italian cuisines. Our favorites are Scooter on the Wall, Big Yellow Door, and QD\'s. Check out one of these joints for some fantastic food.
H 8, Satyaniketan Road, Opp. Venkateshwara College, South Moti Bagh, New Delhi
Shop 15, Opposite Venkateswara College, Satyaniketan, New Delhi
123–124, Ground Floor, Satyaniketan Road, New Delhi
Satyaniketan, South Moti Bagh, New Delhi
No. 1 & 2, Anand Lok Shopping Centre, Opp Gargi College, New Delhi

Fun Fact: All our favorite chat items, from Papri Chaat and Dahi Bhalla to Jalebi, originated in Old Delhi.

 Old Delhi is a popular hub for street food, authentic Mughlai cuisine, and sweets. If you really want an authentic experience with typical north Indian street food, Old Delhi is a must-visit.

Some of our recommendation are Khemchand Adesh Kumar's Daulat Ki Chaat, Lotan Chole Wala, Jung Bahadur Kachori Waala, and Shree Balaji Chaat Bhandar and Bishan Swaroop for the best chaat you will ever have.
Shop No. 526, Kucha Pati Ram, Sitaram Bazar Rd, Chawri Bazar, Delhi 110006
2867, Bazar Sirkiwalan, Chawri Bazar, Chandni Chowk, Delhi 110006
House No. 112 Chowk Barshahbulla, Chawri Bazar, Delhi 110006
1104, Gali Bhojpura Rd, Maliwara, Katra Leshwan, Chandni Chowk, Delhi 110006

There are plenty of nightclubs in New Delhi along with late night hangouts place in Delhi. The Delhi nightlife is known for one of the best party cultures in India alongside Bangalore & Mumbai. There are numerous night clubs in Delhi with feet tapping music, booze, and awesome ambience.\n\nTap for the best nightlife places in Delhi that are the safest party junction in the city redefining the meaning of fun for you.
Delhi\'s favorite nightlife hub since the 90s.
An energetic, fun environment and the exotic range of cuisines - European, Thai, and Mexican.
1st Floor, DDA Shopping Complex, Aurobindo Place, Hauz Khas, New Delhi
Shangri-La\'s Eros Hotel Complex, 19, Ashoka Road, Above Kanishka Shopping Mall Arcade, Janpath, New Delhi
Comical bars and late night parties.
Hotel Samrat, Kautilya Marg, Chanakyapuri, New Delhi
Spacious dance floor with futuristic decor.

You haven\’t lived fully if you haven\’t experienced Delhi\’s extravagant bar hopping scene. For people who want to simply chill with friends with a beer in hand a great music around, here are the best night clubs in Delhi.\n\nA fun nightlife in Delhi is an incomplete without these cosy spots around. If you want to experience nightlife with South Delhi, then you will have ample of options in lounges there.
The amazing range of Cocktails and the classy atmosphere.
The delightful cuisines and rooftop seating.
A great combination of Booze & Sufi music.
Probably the most enormous variety of Beer you\'d ever find in Delhi.
The most tempting Beers brewed on-site.
Music Locales - Visit Hippest Music Venues

Friends and music are the best remedy to help kill the stress of work. Which is why, Delhi has some of the coolest and hippest music venues for music lovers of all kinds of the best nightlife in Delhi for singles.\n\nFrom light band performances, karaoke nights, to soft music play in the background, Delhi nightlife has it all. There are many places where you can spend the best nightlife in Delhi.
Live band performance by rising bands across the country.
Different kinds of music events almost everyday, as in, a Sufi Night one day and a DJ Night the next.
Karaoke Nights and heavy Rock music.
A rooftop cafe with a pretty decor and laid back background music to enjoy your food with.

We can\’t even imagine best nightlife in Delhi without booze. It is an essential ingredient. It\’s difficult to find a good shop selling alcohol at night in Delhi NCR region, but not if you know where to look!

The best of thekas are open till midnight and some even have post shacks alongside them so that people can sit, drink, and discuss crazy life stories with friends and experience the best of New Delhi nightlife!

After all, nightlife in Delhi for singles can be best experienced with a bunch of good friends and a pint!
A posh liquor shop and dining place alongside.
The finest quality wine in NCR.
A quaint eating joint attached to this decent liquor shop.
Dining - Choose From A Wide Range

Willing to shell some extra bucks for getting the best dining experience? Check the below list to know about the best places to eat in Delhi.\n\nWith lavish surroundings, awesome ambience and the most scrumptious of cuisines, nightlife places in Delhi has a wide range of options.
The home of the \'World\'s Best Daal!\' (Dal Bukhara).
The YBR Mixed Grill & Bull\'s Eye
The Mediterranean food, especially the Classic Caesar Salad & Seafood Rissoto.
Among the most romantic & beautiful restaurants in Delhi.
Road Trips For Food Near Delhi - Try The Best Faraway Places

Who said road trips only take you places? They can also take you to your favourite food! Start your engines and get to these awesome faraway places to gorge some lip-smacking parathas and burgers and experience Delhi nightlife like never before.
The Parathas laden with White Butter.
A fun drive down to your favorite Burgers and Wraps.
Delicious North Indian and Chinese cuisines.
Ultimate pitstop for tasty and pocket-friendly Rajasthani food.
75 Milestone Delhi - Jaipur Expressway Dharuheda Rewadi, Dharuhera
Late Night Movies - Enjoy Romantic Late Night Show

Nightlife in Delhi, India isn\’t all about parties, booze and food, right? If you want to enjoy romantic late night show with your beloved, we have a list of some of the best theatres in Delhi that usually have shown running late into the night. Time to plan that late night movie date?!

If you are not a party animal but love some great music and bowl and want this at the wee hours of the night, we have had picked the best places to visit in Delhi at night for you which you can pick over party places in Delhi!\n\nThink of playing at little pool or go bowling in the night between 11 pm to 1pm with your friends and make it and night both remembering.
Best place in Delhi for Bowling.
Pool and live screening of matches.
It is the main airport in Delhi city. Very important and big airport that serves both international and domestic flights.
It is used for diplomats, government and VIPs.

New Delhi railway station (station code: NDLS) is the main railway station in Delhi.\n\nMost eastbound and southbound trains originate at New Delhi railway station, however, some important trains to other parts of the country also touch/originate at this station
Delhi Junction, also known as Old Delhi railway station (Station Code: DLI), is the oldest railway station of Delhi city and a junction station.
Old Delhi Railway Station (DLI), Shyama Prasad Mukherjee Marg, Mori Gate, New Delhi, Delhi 110006

Hazrat Nizamuddin railway station (Station Code: NZM) is a railway station in South Delhi.

Hazrat Nizamuddin railway station connects all the major cities and was developed to ease congestion on New Delhi

It originates and terminates Rajdhani Express trains going towards Bengaluru, Chennai, Secunderabad, Madgaon, Mumbai and Thiruvananthapuram.
Anand Vihar Terminal (Station Code: ANVT) is a railway station in the Anand Vihar locality of Delhi.
Anand Vihar Terminal Railway station, Uttar Pradesh 110092

Delhi Sarai Rohilla Terminal railway station (Station Code: DEE) is situated about 4 kilometres from Old Delhi Railway Station (Station Code: DLI).\n\nMany trains from Delhi to Haryana, Punjab, Rajasthan and Gujarat stop at this station.
Delhi Sarai Rohilla, Guru Gobind Singh Marg, Railway Officers Colony, Sarai Rohilla, New Delhi, Delhi 110005
